title: 103_s1222
content:
The Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor Amendments Act of 1993-1994 changes the boundaries to include specific lands and water depicted on a map dated May 2, 1993. Section 3(c) of the Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor Act is amended to allow members to continue serving after their term until a successor is appointed. The Act allows for the revision of the Cultural Heritage and Land Management Plan within a year, addressing boundary changes and natural resource inventory. Approval from the Secretary is required for any changes beyond minor revisions. The Secretary must approve or disapprove any proposed changes in the plan, except for minor revisions, in accordance with subsection (b). SEC. 5. EXTENSION OF COMMISSION. Section 7 of the Act establishing the Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor is amended to address the termination of the commission. The Commission established for the Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor shall terminate 10 years after the enactment of the Amendments Act of 1993, but may be extended for additional consecutive 10-year terms if certain conditions are met, including approval from the Secretary and Governors of Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The Secretary will approve the extension of the Commission for the Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor if the Governors of Massachusetts and Rhode Island provide assurances of continued support and the Commission effectively assists in preserving the Corridor's resources. The Secretary will implement the plan for the extension of the Commission for the Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor. The Act is amended to assist in the implementation of the Cultural Heritage and Land Management Plan for the preservation and restoration of structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The Secretary is authorized to provide funds for this purpose. The Secretary is authorized to provide funds for projects in the Corridor of national significance, regardless of public or private ownership, for a variety of opportunities without regard to the type of projects. The Commission must submit a 10-year development plan to the Secretary for funds under this section, including resource protection needs and annual work programs. Funds provided should not exceed 50% of the total cost of the work programs. The Secretary prioritizes projects attracting non-Federal funding. Payments for conservation or restoration require conveying easements to relevant state departments or complying with resource use restrictions determined by the Secretary. The recipient, successors, or assigns shall pay the United States the total cost of all Federal funds made available to such project reduced pro rata over the useful life of the improvements funded or the increased value of the project attributable to the funds as determined at the time of the conversion, use, or disposal, whichever is greater. Conversion, use, or disposal of the resources assisted for purposes contrary to the purposes of this Act is prohibited. The Secretary has the authority to determine if the conversion, use, or disposal of resources assisted under this Act is contrary to its purposes. In such cases, the United States has the right to reimbursement of all funds expended or the proportion of increased value of the resources attributable to those funds. SEC. 7. LOCAL AUTHORITY.

Section 5 of the Act establishes the Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The amendment clarifies that the Act does not affect private property rights or local zoning ordinances.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 10 of the Act authorizes an increase in appropriations from $350,000 to $650,000 and allocates $5,000,000 for fiscal years 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, and beyond for development funds.
